perturbation.original_text: The phrase "Confidential Information" means information meeting all of the following criteria: 1) The information is a trade secret or other non-public, proprietary information owned by a Party or its direct and indirect subsidiaries under Applicable Law (this Party is referred to at times in this Section as the "Disclosing Party"); and 2) The other Party (referred to at times in this Section as the "Receiving Party") requests such information from the Disclosing Party for the Authorized Purpose during the Term (i.e., neither Party wants unsolicited Confidential Information from the other Party); and 3) The Disclosing Party discloses such requested information to the Receiving Party during the Term either labelled as "Confidential" or words of similar intent, or describes the disclosed information in reasonable detail in a written notice to the Receiving Party delivered, either at the time of disclosure or within five (5) days of disclosure. If a Disclosing Party neglects to label or deliver timely written notice to the Receiving Party identifying the disclosed information as confidential in nature, the disclosed information will only be treated as Confidential Information under this Agreement if the Disclosing Party is able to demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that the Receiving Party knew that the disclosed information was a trade secret or other non-public, proprietary information of the Disclosing Party at the time of disclosure.
perturbation.changed_text: The phrase "Confidential Information" means information meeting all of the following criteria: 1) The information is a trade secret or other non-public, proprietary information owned by a Party or its direct and indirect subsidiaries under Applicable Law (this Party is referred to at times in this Section as the "Disclosing Party"); and 2) The other Party (referred to at times in this Section as the "Receiving Party") requests such information from the Disclosing Party for the Authorized Purpose during the Term (i.e., neither Party wants unsolicited Confidential Information from the other Party); and 3) The Disclosing Party discloses such requested information to the Receiving Party during the Term either labelled as "Confidential" or words of similar intent, or describes the disclosed information in reasonable detail in a written notice to the Receiving Party delivered, either at the time of disclosure or within five (5) days of disclosure. If a Disclosing Party neglects to label or deliver timely written notice to the Receiving Party identifying the disclosed information as confidential in nature, the disclosed information will be treated as Confidential Information under this Agreement regardless of whether the Disclosing Party is able to demonstrate that the Receiving Party knew that the disclosed information was a trade secret or other non-public, proprietary information of the Disclosing Party at the time of disclosure.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the requirement for the Disclosing Party to prove the Receiving Party's knowledge of the confidential nature of the information, we are changing what defines confidential information under the agreement. This may contradict the Illinois Trade Secrets Act, which requires demonstrating knowledge or use. If the Receiving Party unknowingly receives unlabeled confidential information, they might not be bound by confidentiality, which is a legal risk.
perturbation.law_explanation: The modification contradicts the ITSA, which requires proof that the defendant knew or had reason to know the information was a trade secret. By stating that information will be treated as confidential regardless of the Receiving Party's knowledge, the contract could potentially protect information that doesn't meet the statutory definition of a trade secret, thereby altering the legally established requirements for trade secret protection.

perturbation.original_text: If Buyer fails to pay Seller an amount owed under this Agreement by the invoice due date, then Buyer will owe Seller: (i) the delinquent amount; and (ii) a late payment fee equal to two percent (2%) of the delinquent amount for each full or partial calendar month past the invoice due date that the delinquent amount remains unpaid. In addition, if Seller has to file litigation to collect the amount owed and Seller prevails in the litigation, Buyer will reimburse Seller for actual, reasonable, substantiated out-of-pocket expenses incurred by Seller in collecting the delinquent amount and accrued late payment fees on the delinquent amount.
perturbation.changed_text: If Buyer fails to pay Seller an amount owed under this Agreement by the invoice due date, then Buyer will owe Seller: (i) the delinquent amount; and (ii) a late payment fee equal to five percent (5%) of the delinquent amount for each full or partial calendar month past the invoice due date that the delinquent amount remains unpaid. In addition, if Seller has to file litigation to collect the amount owed and Seller prevails in the litigation, Buyer will reimburse Seller for all expenses incurred by Seller in collecting the delinquent amount and accrued late payment fees on the delinquent amount.
perturbation.explanation: The modification increases the late payment fee and changes "actual, reasonable, substantiated out-of-pocket expenses" to "all expenses". This conflicts with Illinois law regarding permissible interest rates and the types of expenses recoverable in debt collection. Making the expenses not "reasonable" or "substantiated" is a problem.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Illinois Interest Act and Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA)
perturbation.law_citation: 815 ILCS 205/2 and 15 U.S. Code ยง 1692e
perturbation.law_explanation: The modification potentially violates the Illinois Interest Act by setting a late fee that may exceed the legally permissible interest rate. Additionally, the change to "all expenses" contradicts the FDCPA's prohibition of unreasonable charges or expenses and misrepresentation of the amount of debt. This clause now includes any unsubstantiated expenses.

perturbation.original_text: The relationship of the Parties established by this Agreement is that of independent contractors, and nothing contained in this Agreement shall be construed to: (a) give either Party the power to direct and control the day-to-day activities of the other Party, (b) establish the Parties as partners, joint ventures, co-owners or otherwise as participants in a joint or common undertaking, or (c) allow a Party to bind the other Party in any manner or otherwise create or assume any obligation on behalf of the other Party for any purpose whatsoever. A Party will not be considered an agent of the other Party.
perturbation.changed_text: The relationship of the Parties established by this Agreement is that of independent contractors; however, Buyer may direct and control certain day-to-day activities of Seller relating to product specifications. Nothing contained in this Agreement shall be construed to: (a) give either Party the power to direct and control the day-to-day activities of the other Party, except as stated above, (b) establish the Parties as partners, joint ventures, co-owners or otherwise as participants in a joint or common undertaking, or (c) allow a Party to bind the other Party in any manner or otherwise create or assume any obligation on behalf of the other Party for any purpose whatsoever. A Party will not be considered an agent of the other Party.
perturbation.explanation: By allowing the Buyer to direct and control certain day-to-day activities of the Seller, the contract creates an ambiguity in the independent contractor relationship, which may violate IRS guidelines for independent contractor classification. This ambiguity could lead to the misclassification of the Seller.
perturbation.contradicted_law: IRS guidelines for independent contractor classification
perturbation.law_explanation: The modification contradicts IRS guidelines, specifically concerning behavioral control. Independent contractors should not be subject to extensive control over how they perform their work. Granting the Buyer the right to direct certain day-to-day activities relating to product specifications suggests an employer-employee relationship, leading to potential misclassification under IRS rules.
